title: Probot LAME Rip
description:
1               Centuries of Sin	 Cronos, Grohl	 4:09
 		2		Red War	 Cavalera, Grohl	 3:30
 		3		Shake Your Blood	 Grohl, Lemmy	 2:59
 		4		Access Babylon	 Dean, Grohl	 1:24
 	  	5		Silent Spring	 Brecht, Grohl	 3:27
 	  	6		Ice Cold Man	 Dorrian, Grohl	 5:53
 	  	7		The Emerald Law	 Grohl, Weinrich	 5:33
 	  	8		Big Sky	 Fischer, Grohl	 4:51
 	  	9		Dictatosaurus	 Grohl, Snake	 3:52
 	  	10		My Tortured Soul	 Grohl, Wagner	 5:00
 	  	11		Sweet Dreams	 Grohl, King Diamond	 12:08

If you had to summarize drummer Dave Grohl&#039;s impact with only two words, they would be "grunge" and "alternative." Grohl played alongside the late Kurt Cobain in the grunge powerhouse Nirvana -- whose impact was truly enormous -- and he continued in a grunge-minded direction after forming the Foo Fighters in 1995. The word "metal," however, doesn&#039;t immediately come to mind when Grohl&#039;s &#039;90s contributions are discussed; while Nirvana and the Foo Fighters both had metal influences, they weren&#039;t metal bands in the strict sense -- they were more hard rock than metal. Of course, there has often been a fine line between metal and hard rock, which are closely related even though they aren&#039;t exactly the same -- and given Grohl&#039;s fondness for metal, a straight-up metal project like Probot was long overdue. This CD is neither grunge nor post-grunge; a definite departure from Nirvana and the Foo Fighters, Probot is metal all the way and features well-known headbanger vocalists like King Diamond, Max Cavalera (of Sepultura and Soulfly fame), and MotÃƒÂ¶rhead&#039;s Lemmy Kilmister. Grohl&#039;s idea was to feature different metalheads he has long admired, and by doing so, he ends up traveling all over the metal map. The drummer&#039;s affection for thrash is evident when he joins forces with Kilmister on "Shake Your Blood" and Cronos (of Venom fame) on "Centuries of War"; meanwhile, Corrosion of Conformity icon Mike Dean&#039;s inspired performance on "Access Babylon" takes the album into hardcore territory. Equally memorable are "Red War" (the ferocious, Sepultura-like alt-metal offering that features Cavalera) and "Sweet Dreams," which features Diamond but is closer to the Black Sabbath worship of stoner rock than the Judas Priest-minded power metal that Diamond was known for in his &#039;80s/early-&#039;90s heyday. And whatever the style of metal that he is embracing, Grohl&#039;s drumming is passionate throughout this fine album, which is as rewarding as it is unpredictable.
